Voiced palatal lateral approximant

\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\n
\n\t\n\t\n\t\t28 languages\n\t\n\t
\n\n\t\t

    \n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t
    Consonantal sound
    \n
    Voiced palatal lateral approximant
    \xca\x8e
    IPA Number157
    Audio sample
    \n
    source · help
    Encoding
    Entity (decimal)&#654;
    Unicode (hex)U+028E
    X-SAMPAL
    Braille
    \n\n\n\n\n
    Image\n
    \n
    \n
    Voiced alveolo-palatal lateral approximant
    l\xcc\xa0\xca\xb2
    \xca\x8e\xcc\x9f
    \xc8\xb4
    \n

    The voiced palatal lateral approximant is a type of consonantal sound used in some spoken languages. The symbol in the International Phonetic Alphabet that represents this sound is ⟨\xca\x8e⟩, a rotated lowercase letter ⟨y⟩ (not to be confused with lowercase lambda, ⟨\xce\xbb⟩), and the equivalent X-SAMPA symbol is L.\n

    Many languages that were previously thought to have a palatal lateral approximant actually have a lateral approximant that is, broadly, alveolo-palatal; that is to say, it is articulated at a place in-between the alveolar ridge and the hard palate (excluded), and it may be variously described as alveolo-palatal, lamino-postalveolar,[1] or postalveolo-prepalatal.[2] None of the 13 languages investigated by Recasens (2013), many of them Romance, has a \'true\' palatal.[3] That is likely the case for several other languages listed here. Some languages, like Portuguese and Catalan, have a lateral approximant that varies between alveolar and alveolo-palatal.[4]\n

    There is no dedicated symbol in the International Phonetic Alphabet that represents the alveolo-palatal lateral approximant. If precision is desired, it may be transcribed ⟨l\xcc\xa0\xca\xb2⟩ or ⟨\xca\x8e\xcc\x9f⟩; they are essentially equivalent because the contact includes both the blade and body (but not the tip) of the tongue. There is also a non-IPA letter ⟨\xc8\xb4⟩ ("l", plus the curl found in the symbols for alveolo-palatal sibilant fricatives ⟨\xc9\x95, \xca\x91⟩), used especially in Sinological circles.\n

    The voiced palatal lateral approximant contrasts phonemically with its voiceless counterpart /\xca\x8e\xcc\xa5/ in the Xumi language spoken in China.[5][6]\n

    \n\n

    Features[edit]

    \n

    Features of the voiced palatal lateral approximant:\n

    \n
    • Its manner of articulation is approximant, which means it is produced by narrowing the vocal tract at the place of articulation, but not enough to produce a turbulent airstream.
      • \n
    • Its place of articulation is palatal, which means it is articulated with the middle or back part of the tongue raised to the hard palate.
      • \n
    • Its phonation is voiced, which means the vocal cords vibrate during the articulation.
      • \n
    • It is an oral consonant, which means air is allowed to escape through the mouth only.
      • \n
    • It is a lateral consonant, which means it is produced by directing the airstream over the sides of the tongue, rather than down the middle.
      • \n
    • The airstream mechanism is pulmonic, which means it is articulated by pushing air solely with the intercostal muscles and diaphragm, as in most sounds.
    \n

    Occurrence[edit]

    \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

    Aromanianljepuri[\xcb\x88\xca\x8ee\xcc\x9epuri]\'rabbit\'\n
    Astur-LeoneseAsturianllingua[\xcb\x88\xca\x8e\xc4\xa9\xc5\x8b\xc9\xa1wa\xcc\x9d]\'language\'Where /\xca\x8e/ is absent due to a ye\xc3\xadsmo-like merger, it is replaced by different sounds (depending on dialect) and spelled ⟨\xe1\xb8\xb7\xe1\xb8\xb7⟩.\n
    Leonese\n
    Mirandeselh\xc3\xa9ngua[\xcb\x88\xca\x8e\xc9\x9b\xcc\x83\xc9\xa1w\xc9\x90]\n
    Aymarallaki[\xca\x8eaki]\'sad\'\n
    Basquebonbilla[bo\xcc\x9embi\xca\x8ea\xcc\xa0]\'bulb\'\n
    Bretonfamilh[fa\xcc\xa0mi\xca\x8e]\'family\'\n
    Bulgarian\xd0\xbb\xd1\x8e\xd0\xb1\xd0\xbe\xd0\xb2[l\xcc\xa0\xca\xb2ubof]\'love\'Alveolo-palatal.[citation needed]\n
    CatalanStandardllac[\xcb\x88\xca\x8e\xcc\x9fa\xcc\xa0k]\'lake\'Alveolo-palatal.[2] See Catalan phonology\n
    Eastern Aragonclau[\xcb\x88k\xca\x8e\xcc\x9fa\xcc\xa0\xca\x8a\xcc\xaf]\'key\'Allophone of /l/ in consonant clusters.\n
    EnglishAustralianmillion[\xcb\x88m\xc9\xaa\xca\x8e\xc9\x99n]\'million\'A frequent allophone of the sequence /lj/\n
    Canadian (Atlantic and Newfoundland)\n
    County Donegal[7]Allophone of the sequence /lj/.[7]\n
    General American[8]A frequent allophone of the sequence /lj/; sometimes realized as [jj].[8] See English phonology\n
    Hiberno-EnglishA frequent allophone of the sequence /lj/\n
    New England\n
    New Zealand\n
    Received Pronunciation\n
    South African\n
    Southern American\n
    Philippinegorilla[go\xcb\x88\xc9\xbe\xc9\xaa\xca\x8e\xc9\x90]\'gorilla\'Common realization of ⟨ll⟩ between vowels due to Spanish influence.[9]\n
    Enindhilyagwaangalya[a\xc5\x8bal\xcc\xa0\xca\xb2a]\'place\'Laminal post-alveolar\n
    Faroese[10]telgja[\xcb\x88t\xca\xb0\xc9\x9b\xca\x8et\xcd\xa1\xca\x83a]\'to carve\'Allophone of /l/ before palatal consonants.[10] Sometimes voiceless [\xca\x8e\xcc\xa5].[10] See Faroese phonology\n
    Franco-Proven\xc3\xa7albalyi[ba\xca\x8ei]\'give\'\n
    FrenchSome dialects[11]papillon[papi\xca\x8e\xc9\x92\xcc\x83]\'butterfly\'Corresponds to /j/ in modern standard French. See French phonology\n
    GalicianStandardillado[i\xcb\x88\xca\x8ea\xcc\xa0\xc3\xb0o\xcc\x9d]\'insulated\'Many Galician speakers are nowadays ye\xc3\xadstas because of influence from Spanish\n
    Greek\xce\xae\xce\xbb\xce\xb9\xce\xbf\xcf\x82[\xcb\x88i\xca\x8eos] (help\xc2\xb7info)\'sun\'Postalveolar.[12] See Modern Greek phonology\n
    HungarianNorthern dialects[13]lyuk[\xca\x8euk]\'hole\'Alveolo-palatal.[14] Modern Standard Hungarian has undergone a phenomenon akin to Spanish ye\xc3\xadsmo, merging /\xca\x8e/ into /j/. See Hungarian ly and Hungarian phonology\n
    Irishduille[\xcb\x88d\xcc\xaa\xcb\xa0\xc9\xaal\xcc\xa0\xca\xb2\xc9\x99]\'leaf\'Alveolo-palatal. Some dialects contrast it with palatalized alveolar /l\xca\xb2/. See Irish phonology\n
    Italian[2]figlio[\xcb\x88fi\xca\x8e\xcb\x90o] (help\xc2\xb7info)\'son\'Alveolo-palatal.[2] Realized as fricative [\xca\x8e\xcc\x9d] in a large number of accents.[15] See Italian phonology\n
    IvilyuatIvil\xcc\x83u\xc9\x82at[\xca\x94iv\xc9\xaa\xca\x8e\xca\x8a\xca\x94at]\'the speaking [Ivilyuat]\' (\'Ivilyuat language\')\n
    Latvian\xc4\xbcaudis[\xca\x8e\xc3\xa0wdis]\'people\'See Latvian phonology\n
    Mapudungunaylla[\xcb\x88\xc9\x90j\xca\x8e\xc9\x9c]\'nine\'See Mapuche language\n
    NorwegianNorthern and central dialects[16]alle[\xc9\x91\xca\x8e\xcb\x90e]\'all\'See Norwegian phonology\n
    OccitanStandardmiralhar[mi\xc9\xbea\xcc\xa0\xcb\x88\xca\x8ea\xcc\xa0]\'to reflect\'See Occitan phonology\n
    PaiwanStandardveljevelj[v\xc9\x99\xca\x8e\xc9\x99v\xc9\x99\xca\x8e]\'banana\'See Paiwan language\n
    PortugueseStandardralho[\xcb\x88\xca\x81a\xca\x8eu]\'I scold\'Alveolo-palatal in European Portuguese.[17] May instead be [l\xca\xb2], [l] (Northeast) or [j] (Caipira), especially before unrounded vowels.[18][19] See Portuguese phonology\n
    Many dialects[20]\nsand\xc3\xa1lia\n[s\xc9\x90\xcc\x83\xcb\x88da\xcc\xa0l\xcc\xa0\xca\xb2\xc9\x90]\n\'sandal\'\nPossible realization of post-stressed /li/ plus vowel.\n
    Quechua[21]qallu[qa\xca\x8e\xca\x8a]\'tongue\'\n
    RomanianTransylvanian dialects[22]lingur\xc4\x83[\xcb\x88\xca\x8eun\xc9\xa1ur\xc9\x99]\'spoon\'Corresponds to [l][in which environments?] in standard Romanian. See Romanian phonology\n
    Scottish Gaelic[23]till[t\xca\xb2\xca\xb0i\xcb\x90\xca\x8e]\'return\'Alveolo-palatal.[citation needed] See Scottish Gaelic phonology\n
    Serbo-Croatian[24]\n\xd1\x99\xd1\x83\xd1\x99a\xd1\x88\xd0\xba\xd0\xb0 / ljulja\xc5\xa1ka[\xca\x8e\xcc\x9f\xc7\x94\xca\x8e\xcc\x9f\xc3\xa4\xcb\x90\xca\x82k\xc3\xa4]\'swing (seat)\'Palato-alveolar.[24] See Serbo-Croatian phonology\n
    Sissanopiyl[pi\xca\x8e]\'fish\'\n
    Slovak\xc4\xbe\xc3\xbabi\xc5\xa5[\xcb\x88\xca\x8eu\xcc\x9e\xcb\x90bi\xcc\x9ec] (help\xc2\xb7info)\'to love\'Merges with /l/ in western dialects. See Slovak phonology\n
    Spanish[25]Andean (from Argentina to Colombia)caballo[ka\xcc\xa0\xcb\x88\xce\xb2a\xcc\xa0\xca\x8e\xc3\xb6]\'horse\'Found in traditional speakers in Peninsular Spanish. Also found in Andean countries and Paraguay. For most speakers, this sound has merged with /\xca\x9d/, a phenomenon called ye\xc3\xadsmo. See Spanish phonology\n
    Castilian, Aragonese and Catalonian outside of large cities[26]\n
    Central areas in Extremadura\n
    Eastern and southwestern Manchego[citation needed]\n
    Murcian\n
    Paraguayan[27]\n
    Philippine\n
    Very few areas in Andalusia\n
    XumiLower[5][\xca\x8e\xcc\x9fo\xcb\xa9\xcb\xa5]\'musk deer\'Alveolo-palatal; contrasts with the voiceless /\xca\x8e\xcc\xa5/.[5][6]\n
    Upper[6][\xca\x8e\xcc\x9f\xc9\x9b\xcb\xa6]\'correct, right\'\n
    \n

    See also[edit]

    \n
